'Double-stranded' ('ds') 'RNA viruses' are a diverse group of viruses that vary
widely in host range (humans, animals, plants, fungi, and bacteria), genome
segment number (one to twelve) and virion organization (T-number, capsid layers
or turrets). Members of this group include the rotaviruses, known globally as a
common cause of gastroenteritis in young children, and bluetongue virus, an
economically important pathogen of cattle and sheep.

Of these families, the [[Reoviridae]] is the largest and most diverse in terms
of host range.

In recent years virus particle assembly, virus-cell interactions, and viral
pathogenesis, approaches for the development of novel antiviral strategies or
agents can be designed.
